data.text: When looking at breathability, the better jackets have an RET value. This is a moisture retention value. The lower the number the better the breathability. A lot of Goretex gear is RET of 9, which is good. Goretex Pro can be down to 6 and in some cases 3. I have a Decathlon jacket of RET 6, which is great. This MH900 jacket is being discontinued but I have just looked and there are other jackets in their mountain hiking range with RET of 6. I saw advise recently that rock climbing jackets are great for cycling as they are designed for mobility, exertion, and wearing a helmet under the hood. NB I am a fan of Decathlon because all of their gear is affordable and can do what it is meant to do.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Addendum. Some jackets have zips under the arms (pit zips) that can be opened to increas ventilation. Some front pockets also give ventilation when opened. It might be better to get a jacket that is at least one size to big, unless you are worried about being aerodynamic (not really a concern at touring speeds). A larger jacket will also improve ventilation and this will reduce condensation inside the waterproof.

data.text: The best I've seen, and has an excellent reputation, is US Army Goretex. It can be bought relatively cheaply as surplus on Ebay from time to time. Many outdoors people and survivalists tend to buy it. The US Army researched and developed an ECWCS (extended cold weather clothing system) in the 1980s. It's been improved several times, so each version is labelled generation (gen) 1 up to gen 3. The clothing is also tougher than ordinary raingear, and can resist rips and tears from thorns and friction etc. It also packs surprisingly small. However, I'm not aware of any waterproof/breathable gear that is capable of permanent use in the rain. I've used ECWCS trousers on a motorbike in the snow, up a mountain, and cycling in the rain. But I wouldn't deliberately travel long term in those conditions, where taking shelter is an option.
